comments:
Editing JoinTable through the persistence properties does not work if the annotation is invalid.  Define a ManyToMany mapping with the following for the JoinTable annotation:
@JoinTable(name="FIELDMANAGER", joinColumns = "")

In the perisstence Properties view choose 'Override Default' for the joinColumns and an exception occurs:

Caused by: java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.StringLiteral
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.adapters.java.NestedStringAnnotationElementAdapter$1.edit(NestedStringAnnotationElementAdapter.java:152)
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.adapters.java.Member.editAnnotation(Member.java:246)
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.adapters.java.NestedStringAnnotationElementAdapter.setJavaValue(NestedStringAnnotationElementAdapter.java:113)
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.adapters.java.AbstractAnnotationElementAdapter.updateJavaElement(AbstractAnnotationElementAdapter.java:102)
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.adapters.java.AbstractJavaJoinColumnModelAdapter.specifiedNameChanged(AbstractJavaJoinColumnModelAdapter.java:224)
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.impl.AbstractJoinColumnImpl.setSpecifiedName(AbstractJoinColumnImpl.java:209)
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.adapters.java.JavaJoinTableModelAdapter.defaultJoinColumnsChanged(JavaJoinTableModelAdapter.java:316)
	at org.eclipse.dali.orm.impl.JoinTableImpl.setDefaultJoinColumns(JoinTableImpl.java:201)
Fixed because we're now using Brian's annotation editing framework
